Even if any of the above criteria apply, the Company can elect that person as an Outside Director if the person satisfies the requirements set forth in the Companies Act and is deemed suitable based on personality, knowledge, experience, or other qualifications, with the reasons explained and announced.
A person (usually a supplier) is considered a major business partner if 2% or more of its consolidated net sales has come from the Company in any fiscal year within the past three years.
"Executive" means an executive officer, executive director, operating officer, or an employee in a senior management position (department manager or higher).
A person (usually a buyer) is considered a major business partner if 2% or more of the Company’s consolidated revenue has come from that partner in any fiscal year within the past three years.

"A large sum of money or other forms of compensation" is defined as an average annual amount for the past three years of no less than 10 million yen for an individual or no less than 2% of the annual revenues in any fiscal year for a group.
"Large donation" means a donation whose annual average amount for the past three years exceeds either 10 million yen or 30% of the annual expense of the group, whichever is higher.
"Reciprocal employment of Outside Director" means accepting an Outside Director from an entity that currently employs someone from the Company as an Outside Director.

Dividends on financial assets are recognised in profit or loss for each fiscal year.

Expected credit losses are measured using an unbiased, probability‐weighted approach. Financial liabilities are initially recognised at fair value. Subsequent measurement is based on their classification either as measured at fair value through profit or loss or at amortised cost using the effective interest method.

elements.title: Risks related to Epson’s business operations

data.value: Overall responsibility for risk management in the Epson Group is assigned to the president of Seiko Epson, with group-wide monitoring and periodic evaluations by supervisory departments and risk management department.
Fluctuations in printer sales could materially affect operating results, as the printing solutions segment accounted for about 70% of consolidated revenue.
Vigorous competition may lead to lower prices, shifting demand toward lower-priced products, and declining unit shipments, adversely affecting sales and profit.
The use of Micro Piezo technology in inkjet printers competes against thermal inkjet technologies, representing a risk in the technology domain.

elements.title: Risk Factors: Technological Competition and Market Dynamics

data.value: Epson's 3LCD technology competes with other companies' DLP technologies and flat panel displays (FPDs), setting the stage for competitive challenges.
There is a risk of losing competitive advantage if consumer opinions shift or if new revolutionary technologies emerge in the market.
Epson faces competition from companies with advanced technological capabilities, strong supply capacities, and ability to compete on price.
The pace of technological innovation is rapid and product life cycles are short, which could adversely affect operating results if Epson cannot adapt quickly.
Failure to transition effectively from existing products to new ones, or inability to meet fluctuations in demand, may negatively impact operating results.
A significant portion of revenue comes from inkjet printer consumables, which are also supplied by third parties, posing additional revenue risks.

elements.title: Risk Factors Related to Alternative Consumables, Overseas Expansion, and Supply Chain

data.value: Alternative consumables sold for less than genuine Epson products may reduce market share and force price reductions, adversely affecting revenue and profit.
Epson may take legal measures against infringements of patent and trademark rights, yet there is no assurance these efforts will be effective.
High reliance on overseas revenue and workforce exposes Epson to risks including regulatory changes, geopolitical risks, transport delays, and currency exchange restrictions.
Dependence on third-party suppliers, sometimes from a single source, may disrupt manufacturing if parts shortages or quality issues arise.
Variability in quality guarantees and potential defects may lead to replacements, repairs, product liability, and a loss of customer trust.

elements.title: Risk Disclosures: Intellectual Property & Environmental Risks

data.value: Highlights potential risks such as objections, invalidation applications, and loss of competitive advantage due to changes in licensing through mergers or acquisitions. The company may face substantial costs related to litigation, compensation, and royalties, as well as challenges arising from infringement claims.

Mentions the possibility of lawsuits brought by employees or third parties regarding intellectual property rights, which could force significant financial outlays and diversion of management resources.

Describes vulnerability to environmental regulations both domestically and overseas, where compliance with rules on industrial emissions and waste could require major expenditures and potentially disrupt operations.

Outlines proactive measures such as the Environmental Vision 2050, reduction of GHG emissions, transition to renewable energy, and the development of eco-friendly products, which also open opportunities for revenue growth.

elements.title: Risk Factors: Personnel, FX, Pension, and Regulatory Compliance

data.value: Epson faces risks in hiring and retaining talented personnel both in Japan and overseas. The competition is increasing, requiring initiatives such as proper compensation and benefits, fostering a diverse and supportive corporate culture, work-style reform, and international talent promotion.

Fluctuations in foreign currency exchanges, particularly in the US dollar and euro, affect Epson's financial results due to revenue and expense imbalances. Despite hedging through currency forwards, unfavorable exchange movements could adversely impact the financial position and operating results.

Risks inherent in pension systems are present, involving defined-benefit and lump-sum retirement payment plans. Revisions were made to adapt to changing market conditions, but any negative shifts in asset performance or liability calculations could harm the financial position and operating outcomes.

Epson is subject to various global regulatory investigations, including antitrust and compliance checks. Investigations related to consumer protection in regions such as France, as well as other compliance areas, could damage credibility, lead to fines, and constrain sales activities.
The progress, results, and resolution timing of investigations are unpredictable and may impact Epson’s operating results and future business development.

Epson faces material legal risks, including potential lawsuits concerning intellectual property rights, product liability, antitrust laws, and environmental regulations. Example: a civil suit involving Epson Europe B.V. and Reprobel regarding copyright royalties.
There is vulnerability related to financial reporting due to potential inadequacies in internal control systems, which may affect the reliability of financial reporting.
Risks exist from business tie-ups, as partnerships might be reviewed, dissolved, or altered, potentially affecting business outcomes.
Epson is exposed to risks from natural disasters, pandemics (e.g., COVID-19), supply chain disruptions, and regional seismic activity (notably in Nagano), which could severely impact operations.

elements.title: Discussion on Financial Soundness, Societal Shifts, and Cybersecurity Risks

data.value: Financial soundness is maintained through efforts such as concluding commitment line contracts with financial institutions, ensuring strong financing even amid the COVID-19 period.

Anticipated drastic lifestyle shifts post-COVID-19, leading to reduced travel and face-to-face interactions, prompting acceleration of initiatives under the Epson 25 Renewed corporate vision to address emerging social issues.

Measures being implemented include information security training, establishing cyber security policies, designing a global security incident response structure, and strengthening product security.
